The Standing Forward Fold (Uttanasana) primarily stretches the entire back of the body, heavily engaging the hamstrings, calves, glutes, and spinal erectors, while activating the core and quadriceps for support, with the movement pattern being a hip hinge (forward flexion at the hips) to lengthen the posterior chain from feet to head, controlling the descent with eccentric hamstring contraction. [1, 2, 3, 4]  
Muscles Worked 

• Primary Stretch (Lengthened): 

    • Hamstrings: Back of the thighs. 
    • Calves: Gastrocnemius and soleus. 
    • Glutes: Gluteus maximus, medius, minimus (buttocks). 
    • Spinal Muscles: Erector spinae, multifidus, quadratus lumborum (lower back). 
    • Adductors: Inner thighs (especially adductor magnus). 
    • Neck & Shoulders: Back of the neck and shoulders (ligaments & tissues). 

• Active Engagement (Supporting/Stabilizing): 

    • Core: Abdominals, pelvic floor (to support the spine). 
    • Quadriceps: Muscles at the front of the thighs (to keep knees slightly lifted/engaged). [1, 2, 3, 5, 6]  

Movement Pattern 

1. Hip Hinge: The movement initiates from the hips, not the lower back, by tilting the pelvis forward. 
2. Spinal Lengthening: The spine elongates, creating space along the entire back body. 
3. Controlled Descent: Hamstrings work eccentrically (lengthening while controlling) to lower the torso. 
4. Core Engagement: Abdominals pull in to support the lower back as you fold. 
5. Deepening the Fold: The head releases down, increasing the stretch through the neck and posterior chain. [1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 7, 8, 9]
